title: Jeremy Corbyn insists he's not 'toast' if Labour lose Copeland and Stoke by-election
text:

Jeremy Corbyn has denied he is “toast” if Labour fails to win the Copeland and Stoke by-elections. 
The Labour leader suggested going into a pair of tough elections while the party’s dismal showing in opinion polls continues was not a problem, but an “opportunity.” 
And he said the party was going to fight “very hard” in the upcoming elections, triggered by the resignations of two vocally anti-Corbyn MPs, Jamie Reed and Tristram Hunt. 
The BBC’s Andrew Marr suggested many people in the country were counting on Mr Corbyn, but both his personal polls and the party’s standing are “not getting better.” 
Corbyn replied: “You’re making the assumption that everything is a problem. It’s an opportunity to challenge the government on the NHS. 
“It’s an opportunity to challenge them on the chaos of Brexit . It’s an opportunity to challenge them on the housing shortage. It’s an opportunity to challenge them on zero-hours contracts. That’s what we’re going to be doing.” Jeremy Corbyn arrives at BBC Broadcasting House in London to appear on The Andrew Marr Show. 
Asked if he ever looked in the mirror and said: “Do you know what? I’ve done my best, but this might not be for me”, he said: “I look in the mirror every day and think “let’s go out there and try and create a society where there are opportunities for all. 
“Where there aren’t these levels of inequality. Where there are houses for all and where young people aren’t frightened to go to university because of the levels of debt they’ll get into.” 
Mr Marr quizzed the Labour leader on a sticking point of the party’s campaign to hold onto the Cumbrian seat of Copeland - nuclear power. 
The constituency is home to the Sellafield nuclear plant and next-door to Barrow-in-Furness, home to the shipyard building the Navy's new Trident nuclear submarines. 
Senior Labour figures fear the Conservatives - favourites to win the by-election - will highlight Mr Corbyn's lifelong opposition to nuclear power and weapons. Voters are being told to ignore Jeremy Corbyn's views on nuclear weapons (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Labour chiefs urge voters to ignore Jeremy Corbyn's nuclear views ahead of Copeland by-election 
Corbyn initially suggested he could avoid the subject entirely, saying he would concentrate on the NHS in the run up to the contest. 
He said: “The message to the voters of Copeland is that the NHS is in crisis, your hospital is continuing to be underfunded and understaffed. Your A&E department is at risk.” 
He said the party would be working hard to protect jobs and pensions in the nuclear industry. 
He said his aim was to move to a mix of power supply, “but we do have nuclear power and we will for a long time.” Read More 
Asked if he “still agreed with himself” on the idea of decommissioning nuclear power stations, he said: “We have a system which is a mix at the moment. Nuclear power stations last for a very long time. 
“Sellafield is going to be there for a long time as a reprocessing plant anyway, whatever happens.” Like us on Facebook
